title: Le Pen strains ties with German far-right ally over 'remigration' controversy
summary: The French far-right leader has made clear her disapproval of the AfD party's goal of 'remigrating' Germany's foreign population and people of foreign origin. But it's a political agenda that Le Pen has long been familiar with.

title: Biden says US will begin to airdrop relief supplies in Gaza
summary: The US President also said Friday he was 'hoping' for agreement on a ceasefire deal in the Israel-Hamas conflict by Ramadan.

title: Deadly food distribution in Gaza: What we know about the aid convoy and Israeli gunfire
summary: The Gazan health ministry said over 100 people died and over 700 were wounded during a hunger riot in Gaza City, as the Israeli army, which has organized a food shortage in the besieged city, delivered aid.

title: Navalny laid to rest as thousands gather in Moscow to pay hommage
summary: The Russian opposition figure died on February 16 in an Arctic prison colony, in circumstances that remain unclear. People lined up in the streets of Moscow, chanting his name.

title: Pakistan's worst-case scenario arrives: Rigged elections and an economic crisis
summary: In this debt-strangled country, whose political aspirations have just been smothered by the army at the ballot box on February 8, democracy is but a distant memory.

title: French men are using a new #MeToo hashtag to reveal sexual violence they suffered
summary: Following in the footsteps of actor Aurélien Wiik, hundreds of internet users are posting testimonies of sexual assault or rape using #MeTooGarçons (boys, in French).

title: Italy: Roberto Vannacci, far-right's favorite general is in trouble
summary: The openly xenophobic polemicist is considering running in the June 2024 European elections. But sanctions and legal issues could get in the way.

title: 'In Europe, the environmental transition is hanging in the balance'
summary: Under pressure from the farming world and industries facing competition from China and the US, European leaders are scaling back their climate ambitions, writes Le Monde journalist Marie Charrel.

title: US two biggest pharmacy chains will sell abortion pills
summary: CVS and Walgreens will begin dispensing prescription abortion pills in a limited number of states where it's legal.

title: Alabama's decision to consider frozen embryos children puts Republicans in a tight spot
summary: With almost unanimous support from its nine Republican justices, the Alabama Supreme Court qualified frozen embryos as 'extrauterine children' deserving of constitutional protection. This prevents any in vitro fertilization in Alabama.

title: Over a billion people clinically obese worldwide
summary: According to an international study, the rate of obesity has more than doubled among adults in 32 years and quadrupled among children. Many countries experience a higher prevalence of obesity compared to those deemed underweight.

title: Russia declares a six-month moratorium on gasoline exports
summary: The move comes after the Ukrainian army successfully targeted several Russian oil depots with its drones.

title: Ukraine's Western allies already have a military presence in the country
summary: When French President Emmanuel Macron spoke of potentially sending military reinforcements to Ukraine, he unintentionally lifted the veil on the existing presence of Western personnel on Ukrainian soil.

title: Bedbug panic was stoked by Russia, says France
summary: France shut several schools in October last year over concern about bedbug infestations. France has blamed the Kremlin for spreading misinformation about the pests.

title: We tested Le Chat, Mistral AI's French-style ChatGPT
summary: Le Monde asked the French AI company's chatbot, which was launched on Monday, hundreds of questions to compare it to its American competitor's software.

title: Chad opposition claims soldiers 'executed' leader Dillo at 'point blank range'
summary: Yaya Dillo Djerou was killed on Wednesday when troops surrounded the office of his Socialist Party Without Borders.

title: Musk sues OpenAI over 'betrayal' of mission
summary: The tech tycoon, who left OpenAI in 2018, argued that the firm was always intended as a non-profit entity. He said recent boardroom changes meant it was now effectively a subsidiary of software giant Microsoft and that this was a breach of contract.

title: Ukraine signs €2 billion military aid agreement with Netherlands
summary: The security agreement was finalized during a meeting between Ukrainian President Zelensky and Netherlands Prime Minister Rutte on Friday.

title: A monster blizzard is expected to bring 10 feet of snow to California and Nevada mountains
summary: A blizzard warning through Sunday morning covers a 300-mile stretch of the mountains. Backcountry avalanche warnings are in place in various areas.

title: French intelligence services investigate pro-Russian campaign ahead of EU elections
summary: The DGSI is looking into a campaign led by a former far-right French MEP in the European elections in June, with links to several pro-Russian figures.

title: Second day of violence in Haiti
summary: At least four police officers were killed Thursday and dozens have been wounded since the latest spate of brutality began, with Prime Minister Henry meanwhile in Kenya mustering support for a UN-backed international police deployment.

title: Iris Apfel, known for her eye-catching style and her black-rimmed glasses, dies at 102
summary: The textile expert, interior designer, and fashion celebrity once said: 'I'm not pretty, (...) but it doesn't matter, I have something much better. I have style.'

title: Real estate: Prices no longer adjust, they drop
summary: With a delay, the turnaround can be explained by a lower annual volume of transactions: it collapsed by 26% between 2021 and 2023 in France, according to data from the notaries.

title: Argentina's libertarian President Milei warns parliament that he will govern 'with or without' political support
summary: Faced with parliamentary reticence, Milei scrapped almost half of the initial 664 articles in the sweeping deregulatory measure issued after he took office, then withdrew it altogether.

title: Good Bye Putin! Exiled Russian actress Chulpan Khamatova's second life in Riga
summary: Best known for her role in the film 'Good Bye Lenin!', the actress has publicly opposed the war in Ukraine and Vladimir Putin. In February 2022, she fled with her daughters to Latvia, a country where she is enjoying unexpected success.

title: Swedish parents say 'there's no such thing as bad weather, only bad clothes'
summary: As part of a series exploring parenting abroad, this week Le Monde looks at Sweden, where children's time outdoors is sacred. Whether in rain or snow, schoolchildren play outside from an early age – even napping outdoors.

title: Paris 2024: Six months before they open, the Paralympic Games have mostly been overlooked
summary: With six months left before the opening ceremony, the Paralympics are plagued by a lack of media visibility. This is one of the many challenges the event's organizers will face over the coming months.

title: French foreign minister: 'The humanitarian situation in Gaza is creating indefensible and unjustifiable situations for which the Israelis are accountable'
summary: Stéphane Séjourné, France's new head of diplomacy, believes that 'France must be on the right side of history' regarding the war in Ukraine, and is calling for a 'lasting' ceasefire in the Palestinian enclave.

title: François Hollande: 'France is regarded as a land of excellence for its wines'
summary: As an informed wine enthusiast and seasoned diplomat, the former French president knows that a quality bottle can be a precious ally. He also appreciates the European Union's importance for France's wine industry.

title: Chad junta chief declares candidacy for May 6 presidential election
summary: Mahamat Idriss Deby Itno, a general who rose to power as Chad's transitional president after his father died in battle, has announced his aim to win an almost-certain election, after his main rival and cousin was shot by in an army assault on Tuesday, February 28.

title: EU releases €50 million to the UN agency for Palestinian refugees
summary: While the European Commission has given this agency, the UNRWA, a reprieve, other donors have remained divided over the future of their contributions. Some have waited for ongoing investigations to be completed, while others have proposed additional aid.

title: Even in his Moscow grave, Alexei Navalny is treated as an enemy
summary: The brutality displayed by the Russian authorities during the funeral of Navalny, who died in custody, turned the event into a protest: The crowd, denied access to its hero and pushed around by hundreds of police officers in riot gear, finally expressed its rage.
